sentence.text: ï»¿Our index patient was a 9-year-old boy referred to our clinic with hypernasal speech and cleft lip palate.

Physical examinations showed craniofacial dysmorphic features including microcephaly, round face, a flat nasal bridge, hypertelorism, bilateral cleft lip palate (that had been operated on several times previously), an hypoplastic maxilla, telecanthus, bilateral ptosis with right-sided visual impairment, long philtrum, low-set protruding small ears and a short neck (Fig. 1a).
Anthropometric examination at 6 years of age had indicated that height (113 cm), weight (19 kg) and head circumference (49 cm) were below the third percentile.
Small hands, interdigital webbing, clinodactyly and metatarsus adductus were also identified.
X-ray examination and a cranial CT scan showed a bone right-sided palatal discontinuity of 7 mm.
An ectopic tooth in the nasal entry was found to be causing a septum right-sided deviation (Fig. 1b).
Laboratory investigations revealed the hereditary coagulation abnormality von Willebrand disease.
Further blood parameters showed no further anomalies.
Teachers described the 9-year-old index patient as a distractible child who found it difficult to perform tasks requiring concentration.

Neurocognitive examination using Kaufman Assessment Battery for Children for intelligence assessment [7] and HAWIK-III, Hamburger-Wechsler-Intelligence Test for Children (http://diagnostik.sdbb.ch/sites/testraum.localhost/files/Label_HAWIK-III_090818.pdf) revealed an IQ score of 70.

Psychological testing, using the Rating Scale for Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder as a part of the Diagnostic System for Mental Disorders in Childhood and Adolescence [5] had indicated a three factor structure with hyperactivity, impulsivity and inattention consistent with ADHD.
